notes.title: Res Sub Judice (S.10) vs. Res Judicata (S.11) CPC
notes.content: High-frequency exam area: define, contrast, and apply tests. Cover parties, matter directly and substantially in issue, competent jurisdiction, finality, constructive res judicata (Explanation IV), former suit vs. subsequent suit, and typical pitfalls in problem questions.
keyTakeaways: S.10 stays trial where matter is already pending elsewhere; S.11 bars re-litigation where matter already finally decided.
Constructive res judicata bars grounds that might and ought to have been taken earlier.
Always check identity of parties, title, issues, and competent court.

resources.title: Federal Judicial Academy — Article on Res Judicata

notes.title: Jurisdiction & Institution of Suits
notes.content: Territorial, pecuniary, and subject-matter jurisdiction; place of suing; cause of action; objections and waiver (S.21). Link to common problem statements in CSS on court competence.
keyTakeaways: Jurisdictional defects are fatal; some objections can be waived if not taken at earliest.
Always map facts to S.15–20 CPC (place of suing).
Relief may fail if wrong forum chosen.

notes.title: Pleadings, Amendment & Return/Rejection of Plaint
notes.content: Rules of pleadings (Order VI–VII), amendment principles, return vs. rejection of plaint, valuation, limitation hints.
keyTakeaways: Facts not law; material particulars essential.
Amendments allowed to determine real controversy if no prejudice.
Rejection under Order VII Rule 11 is on face of plaint.

notes.title: Temporary Injunctions & Inherent Powers
notes.content: Order XXXIX rules, three-fold test (prima facie case, balance of convenience, irreparable loss). S.151 CPC inherent powers and limits.
keyTakeaways: Injunction ≠ automatic; establish all three limbs.
Breach invites contempt; undertake as to damages may apply.
S.151 cannot override explicit provisions.

notes.title: Appeal, Review, and Revision
notes.content: Differentiate statutory right of appeal, narrow revisional jurisdiction (S.115 CPC), and review by same court. Common CSS short-note.
keyTakeaways: Appeal = reappraisal by higher court; Revision = jurisdictional/procedural errors only.
Review is exceptional and lies before the same court.
Quote grounds & timelines succinctly.

notes.title: Essentials of a Valid Contract
notes.content: Offer/acceptance, consideration, free consent, competency, lawful object. Frequent CSS essay or short-question.
keyTakeaways: Minor's agreement void ab initio; no ratification.
Consideration can move from promisee or any other person (as per Act's text).
Agreements opposed to public policy are void.

notes.title: Void vs. Voidable Agreements + Quasi Contracts
notes.content: Common traps: unlawful object, agreements in restraint of trade, mistake; undue influence, coercion (voidable). Restitution/unjust enrichment (S.68–72).
keyTakeaways: Void: unenforceable from inception; Voidable: valid until avoided by aggrieved party.
Section 27: restraint of trade generally void (limited exceptions).
Quasi contracts impose obligations independent of consent.

notes.title: Guarantee, Bailment & Agency — Problem Areas
notes.content: Surety's liability co-extensive with principal debtor; bailor/bailee duties; agency by ratification and estoppel. Past papers often test distinctions and rights/duties.
keyTakeaways: Guarantee requires consideration; continuing guarantees may be revoked as to future transactions.
Bailment requires delivery of possession; lien rights differ (particular vs. general).
Agency: principal bound if agent acts within authority or if later ratified.

notes.title: Negligence, Defenses & Vicarious Liability (Torts)
notes.content: Define duty, breach, causation, remoteness; defenses (volenti, contributory negligence, statutory authority); employer's liability and independent contractor exceptions.
keyTakeaways: Caparo-style duty analysis (persuasive); in Pakistan, common-law principles applied.
Contributory negligence reduces damages proportionately.
Vicarious liability hinges on course of employment.

notes.title: Libel vs. Slander + Defamation Elements
notes.content: Frequently asked short-note. Define defamation; distinguish libel (written/broadcast) and slander (spoken). Touch on defenses (truth, privilege, fair comment).
keyTakeaways: Libel is generally actionable per se; slander often requires proof of special damage (jurisdiction-specific).
Broadcast defamation often treated as libel due to permanence.
Always state defenses succinctly.

notes.title: Rylands v. Fletcher (Strict Liability / Nuisance)
notes.content: Classic CSS favorite. State rule (non-natural use + escape of dangerous thing), policy rationale, and modern treatment as a sub-species of nuisance; list recognized exceptions.
keyTakeaways: Rule imposes strict liability without proof of negligence.
Exceptions: act of God, act of stranger, plaintiff's default, statutory authority, consent.
Modern cases narrow scope; still examinable doctrine.

notes.title: Qanun-e-Shahadat (QSO) — Evidence Types & Burden
notes.content: Primary vs. secondary evidence, admissions vs. confessions, relevancy of facts, estoppel, competency of witnesses, expert opinion. Frequently examined via short-notes.
keyTakeaways: Primary evidence preferred; secondary allowed under specific grounds.
Confession must be voluntary; accomplice evidence requires caution.
Burden initially on prosecution/plaintiff; can shift under presumptions.

notes.title: Confessions: S.164 CrPC — Procedure & Admissibility
notes.content: Recording by Magistrate, voluntariness, safeguards, and evidentiary value; link with Articles of QSO. Repeated in 2012–2024 papers.
keyTakeaways: Strict compliance with S.164 formalities is essential.
Retracted confession requires corroboration.
Magistrate must explain rights and ensure voluntariness.

notes.title: Bail, Arrest Without Warrant & Trial Types
notes.content: Differentiate bailable vs. non-bailable; arrest without warrant circumstances; summary vs. sessions trial flow.
keyTakeaways: Police powers and judicial discretion must be balanced with rights.
Summarize forms, forums, and timelines in an exam-friendly table.
Quote relevant sections for quick marks.

notes.title: PPC: Private Defence (Ss.96–106) & General Exceptions
notes.content: Core definitions, boundaries, proportionality, when right extends to causing death; common MCQs and scenario questions.
keyTakeaways: Nothing is an offence done in exercise of private defence (S.96); scope detailed in Ss.97–106.
No more harm than necessary; right arises with imminent threat.
Limitations near public servants/acts with color of office.

notes.title: Theft, Extortion, Robbery, Dacoity — Distinctions
notes.content: Classic differentiation set; define each offence, mental element, and aggravating factors; add quick examples to avoid mixing extortion vs. robbery.
keyTakeaways: Robbery is aggravated theft or extortion; presence of fear/instant harm is key.
Dacoity involves five or more persons.
Precise statutory language earns marks.

notes.title: Arbitration in Pakistan: 1940 Act & 2011 Act (Foreign Awards)
notes.content: Domestic arbitration framework (Arbitration Act 1940): agreements, reference, awards, court intervention. Recognition & enforcement of foreign awards under the 2011 Act (New York Convention).
keyTakeaways: 1940 Act governs domestic arbitration (with court's supervisory powers).
2011 Act streamlines enforcement of foreign arbitral awards.
Exam tip: distinguish 'seat' vs. 'venue' and domestic vs. foreign awards.

notes.title: Interpleader Suits (S.88 & Order XXXV CPC)
notes.content: Where stakeholder faces rival claims to same property; plaintiff claims no interest except charges/costs. Common short case-study in papers.
keyTakeaways: Condition: adverse claims between defendants; plaintiff neutral.
No interpleader if a pending suit can resolve rights.
Decree determines entitlement between rival claimants.

notes.title: CSS Law Syllabus & Past Papers — Orientation
notes.content: Download latest syllabus and browse descriptive papers. Use to scope breadth across CPC, CrPC, PPC, QSO, Arbitration.
keyTakeaways: Align notes to syllabus headings to avoid scope creep.
Scan FPSC descriptive papers for pattern recognition.
Map each topic to 2–3 high-yield cases/sections.

notes.title: Video Playlists & Lectures (Quick Rev)
notes.content: Use selective, high-signal videos for last-mile revision (res judicata, constitutional/mercantile law overlap, general CSS approach).
keyTakeaways: Watch with statute open; pause to cross-check sections.
Summarize each video into 5 bullet points for Anki/notes.
Don't over-consume; prioritize solving past questions.
